text: In mathematical complex analysis, Radó's theorem, proved by , states that every connected Riemann surface is second-countable (has a countable base for its topology). The Prüfer surface is an example of a surface with no countable base for the topology, so cannot have the structure of a Riemann surface. The obvious analogue of Radó's theorem in higher dimensions is false: there are 2-dimensional connected complex manifolds that are not second-countable. ==References== * * Category:Riemann surfaces Category:Theorems in complex analysis
title: Radó's theorem (Riemann surfaces)
